div.p: Be DILIGENT TRYING to BASICALLY IMPROVE ONESELF.
1. The current general term for cultivating something or refining it is xiū 修 (from Han times onwards sometimes also miswritten as xiū 脩, ant.* màn 慢 "neglect the cultivation of").
2. Yǎng 養 refers specifically to the systematic cultivation of higher psychosomatic competence.
3. Lǐ 理 refers, occasionally, to a rather abstract way of cultivating a certain skill or technique.
first rough draft to identify synonym group members for future analysis 18.11.2003. CH
LEIBNIZ 6.4 P. 61: Ut Rhetores exercitia habent orationis et Grammatici exercitia styli, ita ego in pueris exercitia ingenii institui desidero.

bibl.title: Anthologia sive Florilegium rerum et materiarum selectarum

note.p: 1. The well-defined one-sidedness of the confusion is very interesting: I have never seen xiu1 修 written for an intended xiu1 脩 "meat".

sense.def: entrust oneself to> devote oneself to, cultivate

entry.def: The current general term for cultivating something or refining it is xiū 修 (from Han times onwards sometimes also miswritten as xiū 脩, ant.* màn 慢 "neglect the cultivation of").
The current general term for cultivating something or refining it is xiū 修 (from Han times onwards sometimes also miswritten as xiū 脩, ant.* màn 慢 "neglect the cultivation of").

sense.def: cultivate (one's person, the ancients etc); apply oneself to; train and exercise (troops); occasionally also with negative objects: LH 2 修詐 "cultivate fraudulence"
cultivate N (Nuance difference with prep-less construction?)

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

entry.def: Lǐ 理 refers, occasionally, to a rather abstract way of cultivating a certain skill or technique.

sense.def: to cultivate and sort out properly, to practise systematically (a certain Way)
be properly sorted out and cultivated

entry.def: Yǎng 養 refers specifically to the systematic cultivation of higher psychosomatic competence.

sense.def: cultivate as a tradition to V
cultivate as a tradition to be preserved
to engage in the cultivation of the mind, engage in spiritual practice
cultivate so as to show respect for
engage in Buddhist practice and cultivation
BUDDH: to engage in Buddhist practice
BUDDH: put the contextually determinate N into cultivated practice

bibl.title: 大乘心行論 Dàshèng xīnxíng lùn Treatise on the Practice of Mind in Mahāyāna Pelliot

sense.def: BUDDH: functional sphere of the mind > mental pratice (of a Bodhisattva)
cultivate to perfection one's own personality/character> perfect one's person
cultivate a proper conduct of life

bibl.title: 佛光大辭典 Fóguāng dàcídiǎn The Foguang Dictionary of Buddhism
佛教語大辭典 Bukkyōgo daijiten Encyclopedic Dictionary of Buddhist Terms

sense.def: BUDDH: to engage in ascetic practices, practice hardship (self-inflicted suffering in order to gain liberation; in the Buddhist context often used negatively since it can refer to excessive ascetic practices which do not conform to the 'Middle-way'); skr. dūkara-caryā; dhuta; vrata-tapa (see also toútuó 頭陀)
cultivate onself so as to seek spiritual progress

bibl.title: 佛光大辭典 Fóguāng dàcídiǎn The Foguang Dictionary of Buddhism

note.p: (1) leaving densely populated places and settling at quiet place
(2) obtain one's food through begging activities
(3) when begging not to make a distinction between rich and poor families
(4) only to eat once per day
(6) observing rules with regard to drinking liquids
(7) observing rules about the kind of cloths one should wear
(8) the number of cloths must not exceed three
(9) one should occasionally stay in cemetaries
(11) settling in the unprotected open during all kinds of weather conditions
(12) only to sit and not lie down

sense.def: BUDDH: the twelve kinds of practices for removing afflictions (such as the desire after food, fine clothing, sleep, etc.) (see also 頭陀)
cause to become capable (XUN); cultivate the talents of; treat well
cultivate as a virtue 長儉 "cultivate frugality"
cultivate N1 (by drawing spiritual sustenance) from N2
psychological: take good personal and moral care of oneself> cultivate oneself
moral self-cultivation; cultivation of moral reflexiveness
